definition[0]: to try to deal with a difficult problem
example[0]: There is more than one way to tackle the problem.
example[1]: It took twelve fire engines to tackle the blaze.
definition[1]: to try to take the ball away from an opponent in a game such as football or hockey
definition[2]: to force someone to the ground so that they stop running, in a game such as American football or rugby
definition[3]: to talk to someone in order to deal with a difficult problem
example[2]: When I tackled Susan about it, she admitted she’d made a mistake.
definition[4]: to start fighting someone, especially a criminal
example[3]: I certainly couldn’t tackle both of them on my own.
example[4]: The government has failed to tackle the problem of youth crime.
example[5]: She said she couldn’t face tackling the job on her own.
example[6]: Fire crews tackling the blaze were hampered by exploding gas canisters.
example[7]: The police set up a special task force to tackle street crime in the capital.
example[8]: He believes education is the long-term key to tackling poverty.
example[9]: The government announced a new initiative to tackle unemployment.
example[10]: The issue of cost must be tackled head-on.
definition[5]: an attempt to take the ball from an opponent in a game such as football
definition[6]: an attempt to stop an opponent by forcing them to the ground, especially in American football or rugby
definition[7]: a player in American football who stops other players by tackling them or preventing them from moving forward
definition[8]: the equipment used in some sports and activities, especially fishing
definition[9]: ropes and pulleys (=wheels) used for lifting heavy things
